ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Room temperature ferromagnetism of amorphous MgO films prepared by pulsed laser deposition

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials, Department of Materials Science and Engineering
Key Laboratory of Nanodevices and Applications, Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics
National Laboratory of Solid State Microstructures

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Amorphous MgO thin films were prepared by pulsed laser deposition (PLD) under various oxygen pressures. The structural, magnetic, and optical properties of the films were investigated. All as-deposited samples exhibit room temperature ferromagnetism, which depend strongly on oxygen pressure. It is found that the saturation magnetization (M s) initially increases with the oxygen pressure, the maximum M s of 8.57 emu/cm3 is obtained for the MgO film deposited under an oxygen pressure of 2 mTorr. However, the M s significantly reduces at higher oxygen pressures. Further X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and photoluminescence demonstrate that the long-range magnetic order in amorphous MgO films can be attributed to the nonstoichiometry effect and the presence of Mg vacancies.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
It is expected that combining spin and charge degrees of freedom in the same material will allow a straightforward implementation of spintronics devices with new and enhanced functionalities. In pursuit of this paradigm, considerable attention has been focused on dilute magnetic semiconductors (DMSs), in which local magnetic moments are introduced by doping elements with partially 3d or 4f subshells [1, 2]. However, unexpected ferromagnetism (FM) was observed in pristine HfO2 thin films [3]. This type of “d 0 ferromagnetism” [4] provides a challenge to understand the origin of the magnetism. Following this, FM was observed in a wide range of undoped oxide nanoparticles and thin films, such as TiO2, ZnO, SnO2, Al2O3, and MgO [5–9]. However, in spite of the vast amount of work already done, considerable controversy on the origin of the magnetism still exists [10]. One feature in common among all these reports is that structural defects (interfaces, grain boundaries, dislocations, vacancies, etc.) that are profusely present in the studied materials, may well play a leading role in the appearance of the FM ordering. MgO is perhaps one of the best characterized metal-oxide materials in terms of defects and impurities and often considered a model oxide system for investigating d 0 ferromagnetism [11]. Notably, MgO is also an important material for use in magnetic tunnel junctions [12]. The first-principles ab initio calculation for undoped MgO attributed the origin of d 0 magnetic moments to spin polarization of the 2p electrons of O atoms surrounding the Mg vacancies [13]. Experimentally, room temperature ferromagnetism (RTFM) was recently reported in undoped MgO nanocrystalline powders and pristine MgO thin films [14–17]; however, there are still debates whether the origin of magnetism in MgO is attributed to magnesium vacancy (V Mg) or oxygen vacancy (V O) defects. Our most recent work has reported a systematic study of the crystallinity dependence of RTFM in pure MgO films, which demonstrated that less crystallinity can increase the ferromagnetic spin-order and the origin of the RTFM could be attributed to the V Mg [18]. Nevertheless, a deeper understanding of the mechanism of d 0 ferromagnetism in structural disorder or amorphous material system is rarely researched and still missed. Further studies on the origin of ferromagnetism in amorphous MgO are thus important. In the present work, we present a systematic experimental study of the ferromagnetic behavior in amorphous MgO thin films. The RTFM properties of MgO thin films has been studied under different oxygen pressure (
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ ) in order to obtain a better insight on the nature of the defects that we believe gives rise to the ferromagnetic ordering. The experimental results of MgO film deposited at RT under an oxygen pressure of 2 mTorr, published in our previous report [18], are also included for discussion.

Section1.Heading: Experimental procedure
Section1.Para:
MgO thin films were grown on Si (001) substrates by PLD with a KrF excimer laser (λ=248 nm, 10 Hz). The Si (001) substrates were cleaned chemically by standard procedures followed by dipping in dilute HF acid solution to get hydrogen terminated oxide free Si (100) surface, just before loading into the high vacuum chamber. After the stainless-steel vacuum chamber was evacuated to the order of 10−7 Torr, the MgO thin films were deposited at RT under an oxygen atmosphere from 0 to 12 mTorr by ablating a sintered MgO target. The target-to-substrate distance was kept at 60 mm. Thickness of all prepared thin film samples was kept 75 nm measured by spectroscopic ellipsometer (J.A. Woollam M-2000D). The structures and crystallinity of MgO samples were investigated by x-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical X’Pert PRO) with Cu
radiation. The local compositional stoichiometry of samples and their purity were characterized by XPS (Thermo-VG Scientific ESCALAB 250). PL (Edinburgh Instruments F900) was employed to study the optical properties of the deposited thin films. A superconducting quantum interference device magnetometer (SQUID, Quantum Design MPMS-XL) was used to study the magnetic behavior of the thin films. For all the magnetic moment measurements, nonmagnetic tweezers were used and the thin film sample was directly mounted in a straw to avoid interference from magnetic background signals.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
For all as-deposited samples in our experiments, there are no obvious diffraction peaks appeared in the XRD patterns, which indicates the amorphous nature of the MgO films. Figure 1a presents the magnetization versus magnetic field (M-H) curves of the as-prepared samples. These samples were measured at RT with a maximum applied magnetic field of 3kOe. The diamagnetism (DM) signals of the substrates have been deducted. This diamagnetic term was determined from the magnetic measurements on the bare silicon substrate before depositing the films. It can be seen that all samples deposited under different
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ are ferromagnetic with hysteresis behaviors. Figure 1b shows the variation in the M s as a function of oxygen pressure. It is found that initially the M s improves with increasing
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ . The film grown in a vacuum atmosphere is ferromagnetic but with a low M s value of 0.43 emu/cm3. The M s is found to increase significantly (8.57 emu/cm3) as we adjust the oxygen pressure to 2 mTorr. However, at higher oxygen pressure (>2 mTorr), the M s decreases monotonically in the range 8.57–1.97 emu/cm3 as a function of oxygen pressure during the film growth. The low-field data are shown in the inset of Fig. 1a for better clarity of the hysteresis loop. The sensitivity of M s values to the oxygen pressures during film deposition suggests that the oxygen content in the MgO thin films plays an important role in the magnetic properties. The d 0 ferromagnetism in oxides is ascribed to the formation of magnetic point defects, which percolates in the crystals giving rise to the long-range ferromagnetic order. In order to pin down the origin of the FM observed in the MgO films, a careful consideration of whether any possible contaminations, especially from the Si substrates, are responsible for the FM has to be undertaken. To check if there is any contamination of the substrates that might contribute to the observed FM, all the Si (100) substrates were measured under the same sequences as for the samples. All the substrates showed diamagnetic behavior as expected. Additionally, all the processes of the experiment were carried out very carefully; all the tools used for handling the samples were nonferromagnetic and plastic-based.
Fig. 1
(a) M-H curves of MgO films with different
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ at 300 K. The inset provides a magnified view of the low field data. (b) Variation of M s value with increasing oxygen pressure for the MgO films

In order to understand the physical origin of RTFM existing in MgO films and to clarify that all RTFM behavior comes from pure MgO, the purity and composition of the samples were obtained by XPS measurement. In our work, the large value of the special magnetization is hard to attribute to any kind of impurities. If such an impurity did exist, we should have been able to observe it in the XPS spectra. Figure 2 shows the XPS survey scan of the samples deposited at RT under different oxygen pressures. The result shows clearly that the MgO thin films were composed of Mg and O elements only. No impurities were detected in the resulting MgO samples, consistent with the XRD results. From these, the incorporation of any additional magnetic impurities can be ruled out. The Mg 1s XPS spectra of MgO films deposited with different
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ are shown in Fig. 3a. For the MgO films prepared under vacuum and
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ of 2 mTorr, it can be found that the XPS spectrum of Mg 1s core level both exist as Mg2+ bound to O2− with a binding energy of 1304 eV [19, 20]. For the MgO film prepared with
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ of 12 mTorr, the Mg 1s XPS peak can be fitted into two symmetrical peaks. As mentioned above, the lower binding energy peak located at 1304 eV corresponds to the Mg 1s core peak of Mg2+ bound to O2−, while the higher binding energy peak at 1305.1 eV can be attributed to the formation of Mg(OH)2 [20, 21]. It is well known that MgO reacts with the water vapor and forms its hydroxide with spinel structure. In our case, this water vapor may come from the residual background pressure of the deposition chamber since the turbo-molecular pump has relatively lesser pumping speed for water vapors under higher oxygen flow. The O 1s XPS spectra of MgO films deposited with different
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ are shown in Fig. 3b. The broad and slightly asymmetric nature of the peak is suggested to be the various coordination of oxygen in MgO thin films. For the MgO films prepared under vacuum and
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ of 2 mTorr, the O 1s XPS peak can be fitted into two symmetrical peaks. The lower binding energy peak located at 530.2 eV (Oa) is ascribed to the O 1s core peak of O2− bound to Mg2+ [22], which is normally assigned as the lower binding energy component (LBEC). The higher binding energy peak at 531.85 eV (Ob) is attributed to the near-surface oxygen [23]. For the MgO film prepared with
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ of 12 mTorr, the O 1s XPS peak can be fitted into three symmetrical peaks. The highest binding energy peak appeared at 532.7 eV is ascribed to OH in Mg(OH)2 [20, 21], which is in accordance with the corresponding Mg 1s XPS peak. The stoichiometry of MgO was determined from the ratio of integrated-area of peaks due to lattice Mg for MgO in the Mg-1s spectra to that due to lattice oxygen for MgO in the O-1s spectra (area of lattice Mg/area of LBEC) as a function of the
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ during deposition, it can be found that all the samples are nonstoichiometric with Mg-deficiency, which is similar to the earlier report for amorphous MgO films [24]. Furthermore, the nonstoichiometry of the amorphous MgO films is affected by the oxygen ambient significantly, as shown in Fig. 4, the variation trend of the Mg-deficiency is consistent with the oxygen pressure dependence of magnetization of MgO thin films. As we know, the formation energy of cation vacancy decreases with increasing oxygen atmosphere, so the amount of cation vacancy would increase with increasing oxygen pressures. Furthermore, there is critical value of oxygen pressure for the stoichiometry in oxides according to the first-principles calculation, when the oxygen pressure is above the critical value, it would be easier to get cation deficient nonstoichiometric oxides. Accordingly, we deduce that the critical oxygen pressure is around 1 mTorr for the MgO samples in our experiments, so the amount of Mg vacancies increase abruptly between 1 and 2 mTorr. At higher
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ , more oxygen atoms would form interstitials (O i) or replace the Mg lattice site and form the oxygen antisites (O Mg), so the formation of Mg vacancies would be suppressed. On the other hand, the O i and O Mg could break up the long range ferromagnetic chains (i.e., the coupling between active defects) by extinguishing the active Mg deficient defects, which would in turn degrade the magnetization of MgO films. It can be found that the larger the concentration of Mg deficiency is, the stronger the FM becomes. A maximal concentration of Mg deficiency is around 6.5 % for the amorphous MgO film deposited with
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ of 2 mTorr. Thus, it can be deduced that the Mg deficiency, or the V Mg, is responsible for the RTFM in the MgO thin films.
Fig. 2
XPS survey spectra of the MgO films deposited with different
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ , (a) vacuum, (b) 2 mTorr, and (c) 12 mTorr
Fig. 3
XPS spectra of Mg 1s (a) and O 1s (b) for MgO films grown under different oxygen pressures
Fig. 4
Oxygen pressure dependence of the magnetization and the ratio of integrated-area of peaks due to lattice Mg for MgO to that due to lattice oxygen for MgO

To further verify this deduction, PL measurement was employed. Figure 5 shows the experimental data for RT PL spectra of MgO films with different
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ . The PL spectra were recorded in the spectral range of 320–420 nm excited at the wavelength of 220 nm. It can be seen that there is a broad peak centered around 370 nm, which has been attributed to the V Mg defects [25]. It is worth noting that the variation trend of the peak intensity corresponding to the concentration of V Mg is also in accordance with the oxygen pressure dependence of magnetization of MgO thin films. The coincidence of these two trends confirms that the RTFM is correlated directly with the V Mg and the ferromagnetic moments enhance with an increase of the concentration of V Mg in the MgO films, which is consistent with the results of the first-principle ab initio calculation for MgO [13].
Fig. 5
PL spectra of the MgO films deposited under different
$P_{\mathrm{O}_{2}}$ , (a) vacuum, (b) 2 mTorr, (c) 5.5 mTorr, and (d) 12 mTorr

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In conclusion, our results revealed the existence of a close correlation between the ferromagnetism and the magnesium vacancies in amorphous MgO films prepared by pulsed laser deposition under different oxygen pressures. The consistency of the variation of the Mg vacancies concentration and M s value of the samples demonstrates that the origin of the RTFM could be attributed to the nonstoichiometry and Mg vacancies in the amorphous MgO films. These results may propose a further insight into the d 0 ferromagnetism in amorphous material system.
